children.text: Indicator 1: Students can recognize and analyze words.
(Application) Students can identify and manipulate phonemes and words in spoken language.
(Application) Students can match letters and sounds and use them in decoding and making CV- C words.
(Application) Students can comprehend and use vocabulary from text read aloud.
(Application) Students can decode words using short vowel sounds.
(Application) Students can read text by decoding word parts.
(Synthesis) Students can blend sounds of words to read text.
(Analysis) Students can separate two part words orally and in text.
(Knowledge) Students can identify root words and their inflectional forms in text.
(Comprehension) Students can interpret vocabulary when reading independently.
(Application) Students can read high-frequency words in text.
(Analysis) Students can decode to read and recognize words.
(Knowledge) Students can read simple contractions and identify the two words which are combined in text.
(Application) Students can decode using word recognition skills.
(Analysis) Students can analyze complex word patterns.
(Comprehension) Students can identify meanings of unfamiliar vocabulary.
(Application) Students can construct meaning by using word parts and categories.
(Analysis) Students can determine word meaning using prior knowledge and context clues.
(Analysis) Students can expand word meanings using word categories and word parts.
(Application) Students can utilize context to comprehend words with multiple meanings.
(Analysis) Students can analyze word parts to determine meaning and context.
(Analysis) Students can infer how word choice affects meaning.
(Application) Students can apply contextual knowledge of word origins to extend vocabulary.
(Application) Students can apply example clues to extend vocabulary.
(Analysis) Students can apply contrast clues to extend vocabulary.
(Application) Students can apply cause and effect clues to extend vocabulary.
(Synthesis) Students can interpret the meaning of unfamiliar words by selecting context clues.
Indicator 2: Students can comprehend and fluently read text.
(Application) Students can comprehend and respond to text read aloud.
(Knowledge) Students can identify all upper-case and lower-case letters and matching sounds with automaticity.
(Knowledge) Students can read sight words and high-frequency words with automaticity.
(Application) Students can comprehend text by applying reading strategies.
(Application) Students can utilize comprehension strategies.
(Comprehension) Students can read fluently to comprehend text.
(Application) Students can apply strategies to read and comprehend text.
(Comprehension) Students can read aloud fluently to comprehend text.
(Application) Students can apply comprehension strategies to read and interpret text.
(Application) Students can fluently read aloud and silently to comprehend text.
(Synthesis) Students can construct meaning from text by applying comprehension strategies.
(Application) Students can develop fluency by utilizing fluency strategies independently.
(Application) Students can utilize fluency strategies to comprehend literature and other materials.
(Application) Students can utilize comprehension strategies while constructing meaning.
(Application) Students can apply fluency strategies to gain meaning from text.
(Analysis) Students can utilize direct and implied meaning to comprehend text.
(Application) Students can demonstrate the elements of fluency to comprehend text.
(Application) Students can interpret text using comprehension strategies.
(Application) Students can read fluently to comprehend grade-level text.
(Analysis) Students can analyze text using comprehension strategies.
(Application) Students can read fluently to comprehend grade-level text.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate text by applying comprehension strategies.
(Application) Students can read fluently to comprehend grade-level text.
(Synthesis) Students can formulate associations between texts and experiences.
(Application) Students can read fluently to comprehend grade-level text.
(Analysis) Students can analyze how diction affects the interpretation of text.
(Application) Students can read fluently to comprehend grade-level text.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate how style affects the meaning of text.
(Application) Students can read fluently to comprehend grade-level text.
Indicator 3: Students can apply knowledge of text structures, literary devices, and literary elements to develop interpretations and form responses.
(Knowledge) Students can identify concepts of print in text.
(Knowledge) Students can tell what authors and illustrators do.
(Application) Students can distinguish fiction from nonfiction.
(Knowledge) Students can identify major literary elements in text.
(Analysis) Students can identify similarities and differences in text written by the same author.
(Analysis) Students can identify the difference between genres including fiction, nonfiction, and poetry.
(Analysis) Students can recognize different genres of literature.
(Analysis) Students can identify the literary elements of character, setting, plot, and theme in literature.
(Application) Students can identify rhyme, rhythm, alliteration, and a simple pattern in poetry.
(Analysis) Students can identify and describe literary elements and devices in literature.
(Analysis) Students can compare and contrast different genres
(Knowledge) Students can identify organizational and text structures within genres.
(Analysis) Students can identify, explain, and use text features.
(Evaluation) Students can determine how word choice affects meaning.
(Analysis) Students can distinguish literary genres based on characteristics, structures, and patterns.
(Evaluation) Students can interpret literary elements of character, setting, plot, theme, point of view, and mood.
(Application) Students can identify literary devices within text.
(Comprehension) Students can describe text structures to determine meaning in fiction, nonfiction, and poetry.
(Comprehension) Students can describe literary elements to determine meaning in fiction, nonfiction, and poetry.
(Comprehension) Students can describe literary devices to determine meaning in fiction, nonfiction, and poetry.
(Evaluation) Students can examine text structures for characteristics of fiction, nonfiction, drama, and poetry.
(Comprehension) Students can identify how authors use literary elements to create meaning.
(Comprehension) Students can identify how authors use literary devices to create meaning.
(Analysis) Students can examine the author's use of literary elements in fiction, nonfiction, drama, and poetry.
(Analysis) Students can examine the effects of the author's use of literary devices.
(Analysis) Students can analyze an author's use of literary elements in fiction.
(Analysis) Students can analyze an author's style.
(Analysis) Students can analyze and explain literary devices within text.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate text for the author's style.
Indicator 4: Students can interpret and respond to diverse, multicultural, and time period texts.
(Comprehension) Students can recognize that literature from various cultures shows differences.
(Analysis) Students can compare text from different cultures as read aloud by teacher.
(Analysis) Students can compare and contrast different versions of literature from different cultures.
(Analysis) Students can compare and contrast different stories from various time periods.
(Analysis) Students can respond to ideas and attitudes expressed in multicultural and historical texts by making connections.
(Analysis) Students can identify and distinguish the characteristics of multicultural texts, historical texts, and time period texts.
(Analysis) Students can examine and compare texts from various cultures, time periods, and geographical locations.
(Analysis) Students can compare and contrast text from different time periods, cultures, and historical events.
(Application) Students can identify recurring themes in text from diverse cultures, time periods, and historical events.
(Analysis) Students can compare and contrast literature from different time periods and cultures dealing with similar themes and conflicts.
(Analysis) Students can analyze text to determine the influence of time period, culture, geography, and author's background.
(Analysis) Students can determine the author's purpose in multicultural, geographical, and historical texts.
(Analysis) Students can analyze a text within cultural, geographical, and historical context.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate the depiction of human experience in literary works from diverse cultures, locations, and time periods.
Indicator 5: Students can access, analyze, synthesize, and evaluate informational texts.
(Knowledge) Students can locate informational text at school.
(Knowledge) Students can alphabetize letters.
(Application) Students can locate and utilize a table of contents.
(Analysis) Students can apply alphabetize words to the first letter.
(Application) Students can identify and utilize text features to comprehend informational text.
(Application) Students can apply alphabetical order to the second letter when using dictionaries and encyclopedias.
(Application) Students can determine and utilize organizational features of text.
(Application) Students can choose reference materials to locate information.
(Application) Students can collect information from two reference materials.
(Application) Students can use organizational features of text.
(Synthesis) Students can research a topic by gathering information from at least two sources.
(Analysis) Students can use select information from two or more reference sources to meet a goal.
(Knowledge) Students can identify the author's purpose in argumentative and persuasive text.
(Application) Students can choose references to meet the needs of an assigned task.
(Synthesis) Students can compare and contrast information on one topic from multiple informational texts.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate the credibility of informational texts.
(Application) Students can utilize sources to locate information.
(Application) Students can determine which reference sources will provide the best information for the assigned task.
(Analysis) Students can analyze and organize data from informational text.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate the accuracy and credibility of information about a topic contained in multiple sources.
(Analysis) Students can analyze the author's purpose in text.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate information and author's purpose about a topic gathered from informational text.
(Knowledge) Students can recognize expository, persuasive, and procedural text.
(Synthesis) Students can combine new information with existing knowledge to enhance understanding.
(Evaluation) Students can evaluate primary and secondary sources for credibility.
(Application) Students can interpret procedural text to complete a multiple-step task.
(Comprehension) Students can recognize logical fallacies in sources.
(Analysis) Students can analyze factors that influence the credibility of informational sources.
(Synthesis) Students can synthesize information from multiple sources to analyze issues and to make decisions for research.
